author: AngeloMonharti
body:
Copying and pasting from an earlier conversation I had today:

Nvidia has a few CMP HX partner models preparing to launch - these are the mining specific cards. They have no display output which means they can't be used for gaming. Nvidia is also revising ALL current 30 series (except 3090 I believe) to a LHR (light hash rate) version which is a physical difference in the silicon. They are doing this to nerf ETH mining performance on their 30 series cards at the hardware level.

Currently, Nvidia's CMP HX mining cards make no economic sense to mine on since they are way less power efficient, and have no resale value since they can't be used for gaming. However, if Nvidia completely locks down ETH hash rate on the 30 series, they can increase their TAM by preventing miners from cannibalizing their gaming sales. So far, the CMP HX cards look like they are built on 10 series architecture so they will be able to be produced cheaper and in parallel to 30 series.

Lastly, the ARM deal seems to be moving along. Qualcomm has voiced concerns and said they are ready to invest in ARM as a partner if the Nvidia deal falls through. Nvidia says it has 3 other silicon manufacturers who support the Nvidia deal but details aren't known yet. Nvidia's recent rise is likely due to the probability of the ARM deal actually becoming more likely.

In case you dont understand why the ARM deal is good for NVDA, it means that all ARM-based chip manufacturers are beholden to NVDA. ARM is the most dominant CPU architecture for all mobile CPUs including micro controllers in other devices. Apple, qualcomm, samsung, amd, intel, huawei, IBM all have ARM licenses

It allows NVDA to penetrate the mobile market. Nvidia has the highest profit margins on their mobile CPUs because they don't have to rely on partners to distribute chunky desktop cards. They sell the silicon directly. Every iphone and samsung galaxy could have an Nvidia-produced CPU and GPU.

The reason ARM is used for mobile is because of its power efficiency. If Nvidia knows what they are doing (they do) then they know how they can use their proprietary access to ARM to create ultra performant and efficient server chips, feeding into their datacenter revenue.

Nvidia has announced plans to enter the server CPU market. When they announced this, Intel and AMD stock tanked 5% or so. My bet is that they are already working with ARM to deliver their CPU server chips

TL;DR - ARM deal going through would make NVDA pull a page out of 2020 TSLA's book. Downside is ARM deal delays, pricing in approval then having it get denied. Would crush the stock.

author: Gorpachev
body: I forgot what the class was called, but it was business related and we entered a Long Island stock competition put on by Newsday.  We came in 3rd amongst hundreds of teams thanks to awesome stock tips from my Dad...this was early 90's and we were pouring our fake money into Microsoft, Adobe, IBM, and other tech stocks....while most other kids were buying Nike and Coke.  The two teams that beat us had returns several multiples above ours.  My teacher was convinced they were backdating their trades.  :-)  But whatever, it was a ton of fun and planted the seed for later in life.  That teacher wrote in my yearbook he expects a share of the first million I make in the market...I actually want to make good on that.

author: RajivChaudrii
body:
Noone thinks Intel will die off, but plenty, including I, think Intel may plateau like IBM did for the next decade or two.  Intel pouring billions into fabs doesn't guarantee technology leadership as TSMC is investing just as much and has a sizable lead.  

Plus, having a working relationship with Intel, I can say there are still alot of entrenched "old school" management who don't do much but will fight tooth and nail to resist any change or challenge to their power.  Turning that titanic corporation around is going to be a slow and bloody process, way beyond just the CEO.

author: TheLastRedditUserID
body: Former IBM employee here. the stock has split many times I would sell 20% hold the rest. The majority of their business is the mainframe side. Customers also paid thousands of dollars per month for maintenance contracts because there was always some issue that needed to be fixed by a technician on site. A lot of companies did not have maintenance coverage and for those who didn't but needed service the system would create an HSI hourly service invoice once the tech arrived at the customers location. This HSI bill would be so high that the company would either pay it or ask if there was another option where we would offer to retroactively bill them for one year of maintenance coverage which 99% of the time was always significantly cheaper than paying the HSI. They have clients such as Walmart the scanner used is IBM the computer the register the mainframe, the cloud, the analytics and so on.

author: SirGlass
body:
I would just add if you are buying an individual stock the hold forever plan isn't good. Now I am a long term investor if I buy a company I plan to hold for 5-10 years or forever. However 10 years is a lot less time then forever.

I could give countless examples, in 1990 was IBM a great 10+ year hold 100% yes. In 2010 was it; very questionable because in the 20 years a lot of thing changed

So never plan to hold an individual security forever lots of thing can change

My only buy and hold forever are broad based index funds

author: AtrociKitty
body:
>Samsung has a history of being a little "generous" with the description of their node sizes

So does TSMC, it's all marketing. Intel is being forced to rename their nodes because of how "generous" TSMC is, which has led to a lot of consumer confusion. For example, Intel's 10nm is actually smaller than both TSMC's 7nm and Samsung's 7nm, because the true equivalent sizes of these nodes are 9nm (Intel) and 10nm (TSMC and Samsung).

Here's how manufacturing nodes rank based on half-pitch scaling of an equivalent (in transistor density) planar transistor node:

15. 32nm Intel

14. 28nm TSMC / 28nm UMC / 28nm Samsung/GlobalFoundries/IMB

13. 22nm Intel /22nm IBM

12. 20nm TSMC /20nm Samsung/20nm Intel (marketed as “22FFL)

11. 18nm TSMC (marketed as “16nm”) / 18nm Samsung/GF (marketed as “14nm”)

10. 17nm GF (marketed as “12nm” (12LP) by GF)

09. 16nm TSMC (marketed as “12nm” (12FFC) by TSMC)

08. 14nm Intel / 14nm Samsung (marketed as “10nm” by Samsung)

07. 13nm Samsung (marketed as “8nm” by Samsung)

06. 10nm TSMC (marketed as “7nm” (N7/N7P))/ 10nm Samsung (marketed as “7nm”)

05. 9nm Intel (marketed as “10nm”)/ 9nm TSMC (marketed as 7nm (N7+))

04. 6.7nm TSMC (marketed as “5nm”)

03. 6.4nm Intel (marketed as “7nm”)

02. 5nm TSMC (marketed as “3nm”)

01. 4.5nm Intel (marketed as “5nm”)

author: Adderalin
body:
I can create a ton of back tests showing where IBM beats VOO and back tests where it doesn't. There is a real cost in that if OP sells they could only have effectively $8,500 to invest with instead that may or may not beat $10k of IBM in the future. 

VOO would have to grow 17.64% over IBM just to make up for realizing a 15% loss. 

Granted it's only $10,000 but you really don't want to be realizing costs either if you can avoid it. 

There is a lot more things I'd suggest to the OP to invest in besides VOO but it was very important to point out a huge fact the rest of Reddit overlooked - there could be significant capital gains on this position if they sold the shares.

author: AngieDaBaker
body:
I feel like boring is where the most gains are. Take etfs for example. Voo and Vti are boring and they represent the benchmarks everyone is trying to compete with. Large cap well established companies are boring, but those are what drive the market. Ya you would make a lot of money finding a net net or the next Apple as a small cap, but for anyone that doesn’t invest for a living, being knowledgeable enough and patient enough to know that companies like Coca Cola and 3m will always be there and will more time than not offer you a great risk adjusted return is what i believe to be the key to long term investing. 

You won’t find a lot of people here that have been investing in the market for 20+ years because of the lack of popularity, know how, and the cost barriers investing outside of a company ESOP or 401k; but the comments i have heard from some of the older guys i know and work with, they have either been buying into SPY, or things like MetLife, FPL, IBM, and the likes. They bought or kept buying and just let time do it’s thing

author: deadjawa
body:
Dividends aren’t absolutely useless, but they are the least efficient method of earnings payouts.  Capital investments, R&D, and stock buybacks are all more efficient than dividends.  And the fact that the culture of dividends is such that they need to be increased every year and should not go down in bad times makes them extremely dangerous as well.

Some dividend stocks can get away with this, like REITs, but companies like IBM and T are wrecked by their rich dividend payouts.

But on the other hand, reaching that elusive 20% yield on cost number is pretty fucking awesome.  LOL.  A bond can’t do that.

author: Ideaambiguousawhole
body:
TGT: Consumer staples are among the most defensive stocks on the market, and that tends to hold true with their dividends. While Target's dividend is currently not very competitive, I believe overtime that it will become more dominant. Target provides basically the same service as Walmart, but attracts higher wage earners than Walmart, resulting in higher profit margins. Target is also ahead of the fight for 15, having already committed to raising employee wages to 15 dollars an hour across the board. This has not stopped Target from shattering it's earnings Estimates every quarter since the start of the pandemic. There's no reason not to think that Target won't grow it's dividend overtime as it matures.

PFE: Pfizer has a dividend yield of 3.83% compared to its market median of 2.26%. The company has steady revenue for a while with the demand for covid vaccines still rampant abroad, and the eventual need for booster shots will give them additional revenue. In addition, the company is situated to handle it's short and long term debts. 

IBM: Controversial company due to the fact that it recently quietly laid off its older workforce, some would argue a necessary evil in a tech company that needed to adapt. Having said that, IBM is a rare tech stock with a high dividend yield. While many would prefer tech stocks reinvest their earnings, IBM is a mature company that likely would not fully benefit from future reinvestment at this point.  IBM currently has a dividend yield of 4.36. IMO this stock is worth holding long term for the Quantum Computing potential alone, as IBM is working on Quantum Computers that while not currently applicable, have applications that can potentially increase productivity tenfold in the future, and thus would be massively profitable. This is a long shot, as other companies are working on such computers, but still significant upside nonetheless. 

CNQ: Did a DD on this stock [https://www.reddit.com/r/stocks/comments/nx2scl/cnq\_dd\_analysis/](https://www.reddit.com/r/stocks/comments/nx2scl/cnq_dd_analysis/)

AFL: Safety is an important component of dividend stocks, and Life/Health Insurance is one of the safest industries out there. There will always be a demand for insurance products, and stocks like Aflac that are underpriced can make for great conservative investments as well. With a 2.35% dividend yield in a defensive industry, this stock is a safe bet to raise its dividend in the future. It also currently trades at a PE ratio of 7.22, which is very reasonable this day and age and undervalued from its earnings. The stock has been earning at a PE ratio of about 10, suggesting the stock is undervalued by 40%

author: Lingweenie2
body:
Well, VIAC is my largest stock position by equity, so my thoughts won’t come as a surprise:

I think the negativity is overblown. They do own some pretty good content. At the end of the day that’s what matters most. Anyone can get a streaming platform. (With enough money and work, naturally.) 

I originally bought into them right after Viacom and CBS remerged. Though, I had temptations in both singular companies at first. Just didn’t have enough ‘uhmf.’ 

The fact they are together again peaked my interest the most. I think people underestimate them too much, mainly because you’re high off Disney and Netflix’s fumes. I think they’re a solid company that’s doubted too much. 

I held through the onslaught it had in 2020. Bought more shares in the process. Sold off half my stake when the rally blasted off unexpectedly. (A bit early but hey, $80-$95 was damn good tendies.) 

After the implosion, bought back my half back, plus some. I intend to hang on to them for quite a while. Definitely very bullish. 

I like IBM quite a bit too. Own them too. A larger position of mine. Similar to VIAC, not loved much and overlooked. I think with the increasing technology advancements they’ll get their fair share of the pie.

author: Astronaut100
body:
It all depends on how bullish you are about IBM's future. If recent history is any guide, they are a declining business that just can't keep up with big tech. Its five year return is a sorry negative 1.5% (maybe +20% with dividend). In the tech business, if you fall behind, you stay behind. 

They could stage a comeback with their cloud business, so selling the stock has that risk, but odds are that you will be better off buying something like VGT (up a whopping 270% in the last five years) that has IBM in it but also other, more profitable tech companies.

author: Truelikegiroux
body:
IonQ is a complete gamble. Not saying it’s a bad call but I wouldn’t expect amazing (If any) returns anytime soon. They and all quantum computing companies are still years away from the commercialization that they want. 

Competing against IBM, the new combination of Honeywell and Cambridge Quantom, D-Wave, Microsoft, ColdQuanta and a few others so it’s not like they are the only game in town

author: meows_at_idiots
body: IBM has been doing some pretty great stuff. They don't get near the recognition they should in my opinion. I think they will be a bigger player again in 4-5 years. A lot of things are in the works and take a while to ramp up.

author: Lazybumm1
body:
I don't think that vertical integration is an advantage in this industry. Semis goes through oversupply / drought cycles. What happens to INTC in 2023 when their new shiny fabs that have cost >$10B to build are idling because the market is flooded with cheap silicon?

AMD and QCOM simply reduce their order flow to TSMC and call it a day, let TSMC take the loss. 

You're right INTC is still the largest fish in the pond, mostly because they still have tons of B2B contracts rolling. How long do you think they can retain those for while behind? If it wasn't for the immense datacenter demand INTC would be a shrinking company right now.

AMD is eating their lunch right now and growing at anywhere between \~20-50% YoY. Do the math, how long is it going to be before they overtake INTC? AMD offer no dividends because they have better things to do with the money to fuel growth. If anything INTC is going to cut back on dividends too if they're serious about reinvesting in R&D to catch up. 

AMD is not the only competition. NVDA has already announced Grace to launch in 2023 and I'm very confident they will be balling really hard for datacenter specific chips designed for certain tasks. While simultaneously gunning for embedded systems, inference nodes, edge computing etc. 

You also have QCOM who's also competing for more and more market share outside of mobile. Chromebooks are rolling off the shelves with QCOM silicon already in them and we've seen the launch of entry-level laptops with the same chips. 

Everyone is after INTC's lunch and I have yet to see 1 compelling action taken that would allow Intel to level their footing and get back in the game. Until I see that I'm not changing my mind and my investment thesis. This is the next IBM until proven otherwise. If they can't turn the ship around they'll be selling off divisions in the next few years.

author: JonskMusic
body:
Exactly. I don't get it. I mean... photoshop is/was ubiquitous but. its pricey for people. There are people who want to make content and can't afford 50 a month for Premiere etc. Also Adobe has been teasing some really cool AI stuff for years.... but where is it? They haven't really done anything huge in a while.. Creative Cloud is okay.. but its clunky and people don't like paying subscription and they don't like dealing with millions of passwords on an enterprise level etc. Adobe could be great.. but they need to do something big.... although every lawyer on the planet uses Acrobat and calls it Adobe. "Do you have adobe?"... Yet acrobat itself is kind of clunky as well.   


But who is their rival? If you look it up.. None of those companies have much to do with creating content: "Adobe's top competitors include SAP, Salesforce, DocuSign, Dropbox, Getty Images, Shutterstock, Apple, Microsoft, IBM and Autodesk. Adobe is a software company developing digital marketing and media solutions."

author: KawhiLeonardIsSenpai
body:
I'm not heavy on Ford or any cars/transportation. I get they're trying to get into automated cars, but we are years away from doing that. There's a reason why TSLA failed its automated cars launch. If you still want to jump in on the hype, I'd recommend Luminar (LAZR). They make lidar tech, which is used for automated cars. It trades at $24 right now, and it recently poached executives from TESLA and INTEL. So it's high-risk, low reward imo. 

I'm against Disney, but that's your choice. You don't have any dividend plays other than VISA. You could consider JPM, MSFT, IBM.   


I like OKTA, it's a pretty long term hold. AirBNB, fire sale right now. XPEV is a good choice and alternate to Tesla. AMAZON, I really find it hard to believe it can get to 4k. I'd rather take a chance on GOOG, MFST, AAPL, or even NVDIA.

author: r-T00Littl3Time
body: Why would you sell 1 share?  Keep it forever.  You'll be 80 and it'll give you a chuckle, promise.  My Dad was a lifelong IBM'er.  He passed on a lot of various stocks to the 7 kids.  Everything divisible by 7.  700 of this and 1400 of that, but 7 shares of IBM.  I'll never sell that 1 share, ever.
